text: hello everybody and welcome again to re invent my name is aditya and i'm a software development engineer with
amazon web services where i help maintain the aws sdk for javascript
today's talk is about building cross-platform applications using the sdk i thank you all for taking the time to
be here and i hope you enjoy yourselves so it's been about two years since we
started building the sdk and here are a few of the interesting things we've done in that time
in 2012 we released a dev preview of the aws sdk for for node.js
a year ago we released a dev preview of the aws sdk for javascript in the
browser earlier this year we announced general
availability of the aws sdk for javascript in node.js and the browser
now we are showing you that the sdk can be used to build applications not just for node.js and the browser but for
virtually any platform or environment that implements a standards compliant
javascript runtime this is important for us as developers today because javascript is
everywhere it has evolved from being a misunderstood programming language to a
popular high-level language that is being used to build scalable real-time applications
this growth of the language has also been complemented by the introduction of alternative javascript environments that
allows it that allows us to use javascript in so many more interesting ways
for instance you can build applications using javascript and html and compile them down to native mobile ios and
android applications using tools like phonegap and ubisa you can also build applications for
windows desktops and phones that execute on the windows runtime
and more recently javascript is being used to build applications for microcontroller devices like arduinos
and ar drones using libraries like johnny 5 and cylon js
so having said that in this talk i'm going to introduce you to building cross-platform applications using the aws sdk for javascript
to give you an idea of things to come we'll begin by looking at a sample application
we'll then talk about some of the features of the sdk that we've used to build this application
and then we'll go ahead and put the application to other environments and platforms and talk about some of the differences involved in in doing this
so what i'm about to show you is a video transcoder application that transcodes or converts videos from one format to
another the application uses two aws services amazon s3 and amazon elastic transcoder
amazon s3 is an object storage service and we're using s3 to store to store video files
amazon elastic transcoder is a service that allows you to convert or transcode media files from
one format to another now our application uploads files to s3
kicks off a transcoder job waits for the job to complete and then downloads the transcoded files back from
s3 again so let's go take a look at it
so what i'm doing is i am providing the part of a video that i want to use that
i want to transcode so our application is now uploading
files to s3 it's going to kick off a transcoder job and now we're waiting for the files to
transcode and while this is happening i'd like to let you know
that the source code for for for the sample application is available on github at
github.com aws labs slash aws sdk
js sample video transcoder that should be pretty simple to find
i encourage you to go ahead and download it and play with it and maybe even add to it by sending us a
pull request that we'd be happy to look at so let's go back and take a look and see
if our application has finished transcoding files so you see that it waited for
a while to finish for transcoder to finish transcoding the files it then notified us about that and it
went ahead and downloaded the files back for us
so i'm going to open this up
so that's the downloaded video the keynotes on wednesday and thursday are the time when you'll get the chance to
hear about the latest trends in cloud computing and see what that means for aws whether you watch live or you watch the
stream you do not want to miss the keynotes this year
so what you see here is a very high level architecture of how we built the application
the bulk of the uh the bulk of the business logic as well as the lower level sdk calls are contained in the
app.js file what we've also built in is a very simple publish subscribe messaging
system that allows the application to publish messages that other components can then subscribe to
this allows the business logic to be completely decoupled from presentation and in order to put the application to
other environments all you'll need to do is swap out your ui layer and then
subscribe to the messages that the application is publishing
we'll go ahead and talk about some of the features of the sdk that we've used to build this application now
here is some basic usage of the sdk
now the aws object itself exposes a constructor for every service that is
supported uh and in order to and in order to send requests you'll need to construct a
service object and then invoke an operation on it now operations are nothing but methods
on the constructed service object and most methods except two parameters the first being a
params object that contains data that you want to send along with your request and the second is a callback that is
invoked when the request completes the example here shows us making
constructing an s3 service object and then making a list objects operation
on a bucket that we are passing in as parameter as the parameter
so from the previous example if we don't pass in a callback to the operation then what we get is a request
object that hasn't been sent yet now this is really useful because you can now customize the object before
actually sending it the code snippet here shows us attaching additional event listeners to
the success event of the request object there are also many other events that
are emitted during the life cycle of the request and you can take a look at these are documented on our sdk documentation
page and you can go ahead and take a look at them there point to note however is that since the
request object hasn't been sent yet you'll need to manually send it using the send method this is actually useful because it now
gives you complete control of your request object
in addition to all of the in addition to all the life cycle events that are emitted by the request there are two
special events that i emitted and these are the http upload progress and http download progress events
uh that i omitted uh during uh data transfers the event listener to both of these
events receives a a progress object that contains information about the total number of
bytes transferred as well as the content length of the request or response
another another very useful feature of the sdk that we've used in our application are resource waiters now
waiters make it really simple for you to work with asynchronous resources
very simply what a waiter does is that it pulls the resource until it is in a desired state and then invokes a
callback so in the sample application that you saw earlier
we use the resource waiter to wait for the job to complete before we were before we could before we downloaded the files back to uh back to disk again
there are several services that support waiters and to know more about these you can check out our sdk documentation page
online let's now go back to our application and
look at uh the workflow in a little more in a little more detail
the first step to uh the first step in the in the application workflow is to create a pipeline now amazon elastic
transcoder uses pipelines to create jobs it's nothing but a it's similar to a queue
our application then uploads files to s3 and creates a transcoder job pointing to
the files that it just uploaded as soon as the job is created our application attaches to the waiter that
that was to the attaches the waiter to the job that was just created and then pulls the job
until the job is complete before downloading the encoded files back from s3 again
now in node.js the console.js file contains all of the logic
that is required to interact with the ui the ui in this case being the command line interface
there are some steps involved in however in getting the application to uh to run on node.js the first of them being uh
getting and installing the sdk itself and on node.js you can do this using the npm install command
now before the sdk can be used it requires credentials to be configured
there are many ways of configuring credentials but we recommend that you use the shared credentials file
and this is for a couple of reasons firstly the shared credentials file is
shared by other aws sdks like ruby and php as well as the aws cli
and so it now serves as a single point of configuration the second reason is because the the
shared credentials file supports profiles which are nothing but credential pairs that possibly grant
different access to different resources there are many other ways of also configuring credentials and to know more
about these you can check out our developer guide online
now a little while earlier i mentioned that we built a very simple publish subscribe messaging system into our
application so the code snippet here actually shows the application publishing two messages
when a transcoder job has been completed
we then subscribe to these messages in the console.js file
and specifically here you see us subscribing to the request success and the job complete message which then
allows us to print notifications to the console and this is a very simple process that std
out command we are also able to download files
when the job complete event is uh fired and we're doing this using the uh get
our get object operation on an s3 service object point to note however is that we're
using streams to download files and not buffering into memory the create read stream method on a
on a request object returns a node stream that you can then that you can then pipe into another writable stream and that's exactly what we're doing here
so we've got the application up and running on node.js fairly simply very easily
but why should we care about making it portable
well firstly portability means that you now have a single code base that is easier to maintain
it also means that you can now build test and deploy and debug your applications on an environment of your
choice before porting it to other applications and this is uh this is a huge degree of freedom because
environments differ in the ease of in their ease of use
portability also means that you can now easily refactor your applications for instance you may want to convert a heavy
client application to a web service or vice versa
so any application that can be written in javascript will eventually be written in javascript uh jeff atwood jeff atwood
actually blogged about this in 2007 and he actually called it the atwood's law uh what is more interesting is that
we've actually seen this happen over the years a large number of applications that were
previously written written in other languages today have uh more popular javascript counterparts
so let's go ahead and spread the word by putting our application to
other environments the first on the list is a web application a traditional web application
in uh i don't have a demo to show you um here because uh
we're sort of short on time uh but we will talk through it
in uh in in the web application the view.js file would contain uh
all of the ui logic in this case that would include things like uh dom event management and uh drag and
drop and so on so forth there are some differences however in the way that you would uh approach
building a web application as compared to as compared to node.js uh the first of them being the way you
would include the sdk itself in your web application we recommend that you use bower which is
a package manager for the web it is analogous to npm for node.js
there are also several other ways in which you can download and include the sdk with your web application and these
are documented on our sdk on our developer guide online
we also recommend that you use amazon cognito to manage identity and credentials in your web application to
know more about how to use amazon cognito i encourage you to check out the session mbl 401 which is social logins
with mobile applications uh using amazon cognito i think that's happening at 3 15 today so i strongly encourage you to
check out that to know more about how to use amazon cognito that being said do not use local storage
to store any information this is because local storage is only isolated on a per domain basis which means that if
you have multiple applications on the same domain then uh they will have access to each other's credentials
so uh you definitely don't want to do that another difference in the way uh in in
porting an application to uh importing a node.js application to the web is the necessity to configure cars on amazon s3
buckets uh now cars is a web standard cars or cost cross-origin resource sharing is a
web standard that dictates how web pages access resources and external domains
amazon s3 requires that you explicitly set correspond permissions on every s on
every bucket that you want to access and so you'll have and and you'll have to do this in your web
application in order to access s3 buckets from an external domain you of course won't need to do this if your application is also on s3
for an example on how to configure cars you can check out our developer guide online where we actually have a sample
cars configuration that you can use to configure your s3 bucket
now in our console application we uh we logged progress to the command line which was a very simple print dot
standard out command in our web application we use a a very simple html progress element to display
progress but you can definitely also get a lot more fancy and use a third-party library like
jquery ui to display progress notifications the key point here is to however
subscribe to the to the progress messages that the application is emitting uh so so that's the key point
uh in in uh in displaying progress notifications
similarly generic node for generic notifications we've used a simple div element to display uh notifications but
you can also use there are a number of third-party uh libraries that you can use to do notifications like notify js
and mini js again the key point being is the is that you have to subscribe to these messages
that your application is publishing next on the list is a google chrome
extension and i do have a demo to show you for this
so this is our google chrome extension you can configure options using the options page i'm not going to open it up right now
because it contains sensitive information my information

so in the google chrome extension the ui.js file contains all of the code that

for credential and configuration management uh we haven't changed the app.js file at
all if you look at the if you look at the github repository then you'll notice that the

extension looks very similar to the web application there are some fundamental differences in the way it
works firstly uh and the first of these
differences is the manifest.json file itself um in in a google chrome extension you can use the manifest.json
file to whitelist domains that your extension is talking to uh when you do this uh the chrome
extension no longer treats the file treats the domain as external and so cars rules don't apply in that case so
if you're using this application on the google chrome extension then you no longer need to configure course permissions on s3 buckets
to save our configuration we are using uh local storage um this is fairly safe with a google chrome extension because
local storage is isolated on a per uh on a per extension basis which means that other extensions that you may have
involved in installed on google chrome will no longer have access to uh will not will will not have access to your
credentials and configuration and the code snippet here shows us doing
just that uh another fundamental difference in the
way uh the chrome extension differs from from a web application is
uh is the notification api itself now now chrome extensions expose a very rich notification api that you can use to
create uh that you can use to create a different types of different types of notifications
and we've used the notifications so the code snippet here shows us creating a a basic notification using the chrome
extension api but we've also used the chrome extension notification api to create uh to create
progress extensions and to do that you'll need to change the type of the extension from basic to progress
the the create method itself is a synchronous so uh it returns a notification id that you can use to then
keep track of the notification so in case of a progress notification you don't want to be creating uh a new
notification for every progress event you want to update the same notification and and you can do that by using the
notification id of the note of the notification itself
the last demo i have lined up for you is a is an application for

so in our in in the windows in the application for windows rt we've uh there are three core
files home.js progress.js and transcoder.js home.js contains code that deals with all of the uh all of the ui
and layout that you just saw which includes code for event management file pickers and so on so forth
now progress.js file contains code that uh that has a very contains a very simple progress manager that we've
written to keep track of uh progress events and notifications
transcoder.js contains code that deals with credential management and and configuration
again the app.js file has not changed at all we have we have made literally no changes to our business layer we are just porting this as is to uh
to a windows 8 application
so for those of you who don't know what windows 8 what windows rt is
microsoft describes it as a modern api modern windows api surface that is used
to create new new desktop new windows store apps for windows 8.
but very simply what it is is that it's a unified runtime that allows you to build hybrid applications so for instance you can build part of your
application in c-sharp and part of your application in javascript and mix and match and and you still have access to
the same api that is exposed by uh that is exposed by windows by the windows runtime so that's really powerful
because you can build a variety of applications and that's what we've done here
now the way we've handled credential and credential and configuration management in our windows 8 application is slightly
different and this is because windows 8 this is because the windows run time itself exposes a sophisticated api for managing
credentials it's called the password vault so the way you would do that is you would create a new password vault
and create a password credential with your access key id and your secret access key
and you would then add that credential to your wallet now the vault again is very similar to it it's isolated on a
per application basis so other windows 8 applications that you may have installed will not have access to this to this
information this vault is also encrypted so uh it's not it's not plain text and it can't be
read by it's not human readable
we've uh we've managed configuration uh uh using the uh
applicationdata.localsettings api and the way we do this is we create a composite value which is nothing
which is very similar to a javascript object and we we take all of our configuration bundle it up into this composite value and then store it on the
uh local settings uh api the way to do this would be to set it using a key and
it's nothing but a javascript object so you would just set it like you would you would use it exactly in the same way
that you would use a regular javascript object
again for progress notifications we've used windows 8 apple windows the windows run
some uh transfer some progress manager code that allows us to keep track of each progress element and uh the
corresponding files that are being uploaded so it's it's the the progress manager allows you to map uh your
progress notifications to the files that are being uploaded again all of this code is available on

we uh so we've we've talked about progress notifications um generic notifications that is things like hey

uh windows the windows runtime itself doesn't support
uh progress notifications there is no uh native api to deal with progress notifications and so uh we use the toast
notification so we've built our own progress notification api of sorts uh but we're using the
toast notification api to just to display generic notifications the way you would do this is you would get a
a template object populated with the content that you want to display uh create a get an instance of the

then sorry and then use the notification to uh to show to show the notifications that
that you've just created now that's all the demos i have for you
today but here are some key takeaways from uh from
this stock so we've seen the sdk work across uh across multiple platforms and
environments and uh and and uh there are some differences in the way you would include the sdk itself with multiple
with these different platforms and environments but it doesn't require any other effort also it is absolutely essential for you
to uh for you to separate your business logic from your presentation this allows you to this allows you to put your
application to multiple platforms without having to change your uh without having to change your business logic
itself what we've used to help us achieve this is a very simple progress is a very
simple message passing system that we're using to communicate with ui components in in different environments
and what you'll also notice is that when you put your application to multiple environments there are a common set of
differences that you will encounter when you do when you do that and
these may include uh things like uh you know the way you keep your users notified of of progress
events the uh the way you deal with files um you know native support for streams and so on so forth
uh i'd like to end this talk by talking a little bit about uh a little bit about community and
keeping in touch so the sdk itself is open sourced under the apache 2o license and it's available
on github at github.com aws aws sdkjs
and we really like contributions so we encourage you to contribute to the sdk you can contribute in in many ways
you can you can submit issues you can also create feature requests and if you uh want to
go ahead and fix an issue then we and you can send us a pull request that we'd be happy to take a look at
you can also stay connected to us you can also stay connected to us on twitter at aws4js
